ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed a healthier philosophy on preparing for auditions and performances. I also learned how to prepare and give a recital.

I learned new repertoire, and I analyzed the piece I was learning. I also developed skills for playing more musically and had the opportunity to develop performance skills through performing in studio class.

I truly enjoyed working with Mrs. Parisot this semester. We worked on the Liszt Sonata, Schubert's Wanderer Fantasy, and several other large pieces. Overall, it was an incredibly productive semester and I feel like I got a lot of helpful musical insights out of this course.
Better technique, insight into score analysis, intensity of musical performance
Continued working on my concerto and Bach primarily - confidence in performing was the theme of the semester
I continued to improve my violin performance skills.
I learned how to play guitar! I also learned how to prepare videos consistently for lessons, which made me much more comfortable with playing for a microphone and camera.
A greater understanding of piano technique and musical expressivity.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strength of this course is the flexibility to choose what repertoire you can work on. This allowed me to see a broad range of different pieces, techniques, and performance styles. The professor is generally very encouraging and teaches according to what would benefit you the most. The weaknesses of this course really depends on your professor. I thought I could receive more specific feedback on my playing sometimes.
Hard to say because it was virtual

Only strengths!
Wendy is a wonderful teacher and I love being able to take lessons for credit.
Lessons are great! Having them weekly is a good thing. Not much to change.
This was a very good course

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Using the whiteboard function of Zoom to discuss reed scrapes was helpful.

I think this course did the best it could to shift learning during the pandemic. They were very generous to find a donor with microphones to use with Zoom, which drastically improved the quality of sound that could be transmitted. This improved the effectiveness of lessons. I was also fortunate to continue studio class along with lessons.
NA

The zoom lessons were as good as they could be! 
In-person teaching is invaluable, however.
Having videos for each lesson was a good thing for my playing, though I quite miss in person lessons. Looking forward to the fall!
I liked the virtual component since the sound system was good

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, depending on your expectations. After taking lessons from graduate students in the School of Music for four years, I've found that setting goals at the beginning of the year (my most recent goal was to prepare for graduate school auditions) makes for a much richer learning experience.
Yes, I would recommend this course if you are looking to develop certain musical skills or want to learn certain new repertoire.
Absolutely -- lessons are an indispensable part of a musician's education.
I would recommend this course to any student who is serious about their instrument and wants to improve.
yes! Love taking lessons
Yes! Take lessons for credit if you are interesting in furthering your development in solo music performance.
Yes, if they want classical music lessons.
Yes, if you play an instrument, definitely take this course

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had lessons individually with our professor and studio class with the whole studio through Zoom entirely.
Both virtual lessons and in-person lessons. Virtual studio classes
NA
virtual zoom lessons weekly
I had lessons over Zoom
These were remote piano lessons.
